description.narrative: Stöd till regeringen i Mocambique via UN Joint Program (implementerat av UNICEF och ILO) för att förbättra täckningen och kvalitet av det nationella sociala trygghetssystemet. Programmet som nu går in I sin andra fas fokuserar på att stärka den institutionella kapaciteten på den genomförande myndigheten INAS och på ansvarigt ministerium, ministeriet för jämställdhet, barn och social trygghet (MGCAS). Sverige kommer att i dialog med regeringen (främst via ovan nämnda institutioner) arbeta för ökad täckning av mottagare av regelbundet utbetalda kontantstöd samt för en ökning av beloppen som betalas ut.

Support to the Government of Mozambique via the UN Joint Programme (implemented by UNICEF and ILO) to increase the coverage and quality of the social protection system. The program, commencing its second phase, will focus on strenghtening the institutional capacity at the implementing national agency INAS and at the responsible ministry, Ministry for Gender, Children and Social Action, MGCAS. Sweden will in its dialogue with the government (mainly with the above mentions national structures) work for an increased coverage of beneficiaries for regularly paid social cash transfers as well as an increase of the cash transfers' amounts.

The intervention intends to contribute to the overall impact: - By 2020, ENSSBII evidence-based and coordinated programs and capable human resources, effectively reach the most vulnerable segment of the populations. The intervention will further result in the following intended outcomes: - By 2020, clear programmes and policy designed to operationalize the ENSSB II- By 2020, robust evidence and clear advocacy and communication on key components of the ENSSB II- By 2020, MGCAS capacity to coordinate and implement strengthened

sector.narrative: Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The report only covers the last quarter of the year (September to December) of 2017 as the implementation started 1st of September and it is therefore a light report. The UNJP focused on finalizing Sweden and the Netherlands contributions, startup activities and processes. During this time, UNICEF and ILO worked to finalize the programme proposal, budget and supporting annexes and to comply with the conditions for the first disbursement. Detailed discussions were held between UN agencies and donors on the workplan, results framework, delivery chain map, the minimum requirements for the government of Mozambique. Some key results/achievement of reporting period include: =>UNICEF discussed the design of the Social Welfare Services Programmes (ProSAS) with MGCAS and defined the steps necessary to implement this activity in 2018. UNICEF and MGCAS agreed that a mapping and thorough analysis of coverage, capacity and quality of existing social services provided by the government, private sector and NGO’s should be the first step in defining the scope and design of ProSAS. => UNICEF reached agreement with MGCAS and donors on the importance of a solid impact and process evaluation of the child grant start-up phase. UNICEF invited six firms to bid for the evaluation through existing Long Term Agreements with companies with solid expertise on impact assessment on social protection (transfer programme) with the support of the UNICEF Innocenti Research Centre (LTA manager). UNICEF engaged Innocenti to join the impact evaluation team to provide additional support in the design and implementation of the assessment for the care component. => UNICEF initiated procurement process with AIR research institute with the aim to issue a contract prior to the start of the child grant implementation initially scheduled for the first quarter of 2018. UNICEF also agreed with OoR that the focus of their involvement would be on gender and child protection. Discussions were held on the role and level of engagement of OoR in the research protocol and instruments, data collection and analysis and a formal agreement will be finalized by February 2018. Due to prolonged decision-making processes within MGCAs on the geographical location and features of the child grant, the start of the child grant was delayed and consequently, the finalization of the procurement process and initiation of the research. =>Secondary gender related data analysis. UNICEF held internal discussions on the concepts and scope of this analysis. A comprehensive ToR will be developed in the third quarter of 2018 and the gender analysis is planned for the fourth quarter of 2018. => In October 2017, ILO supported the government to organize the Social Protection week 2017. The activities of the week raised awareness and promoted public discussion about the importance of social protection and social assistance programmes in fighting poverty. Participants learnt through sharing experiences on best practices and implementation mechanisms of basic social protection programmes. The full report from the week, can be accessed online =>In October 2017, UNICEF financed a contract with CEDSIF to complete the final business modules in the INAS management information system (MIS or e-INAS). The e-INAS system development was finalized in December 2017.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
